ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This course offers a broad overview of Colonial Latin American history. Prof. Schwartz splits the focus between the Spanish and the Portuguese Empires, with more emphasis placed on Spanish Latin America.
We got a great interview of the colonial period and developed skills of historians.
I learned a lot about new cultures, traditions, and histories. I also learned about document analysis and closely reading historical sources.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I loved the lectures. He does a great job at summarizing and incorporating interesting details.

PLEASE UPDATE THE SYLLABUS FOR THIS COURSE. I cannot stress this enough. It is INCORRECT. We follow a "reading list" that is released after the first week of classes. I had to catch up by repurchasing a whole new set of books and reading the assignments I had missed.

The strength of this course is Prof. Schwartz's knowledge, as well as the wide period of history it covers. Simply from the wealth of stories and areas covered in this class, there is bound to be something that a student will find interesting. In addition, the paper structure is pretty flexible, I liked the second prompt that allowed you to analyze a primary document of your choosing. 
The weaknesses of this course are the organization of lectures and the discrepancy of readings. The lectures jump between time periods, regions, and continents, and it can be a little confusing at times. In addition, the readings can vary from week to week, being either 20 pages or 200, and sometimes there is too much reading to facilitate good discussion because everyone skims it.
The only thing that could be improved would be the accessibility of the readings.

I thought that the topics were fascinating and Prof. Schwartz was very, very informed on everything he discussed. The lectures were very engaging! However, in the second half of the course, I thought there was very little flow from lecture to lecture -- I think the course could have benefited from slightly more structure.

Weaknesses: lectures and readings do not align much. Due to the high volume of reading, I was not always able to finish all the reading and the lecture did not provide enough context to allow me to still gain a general understanding.
Strengths: covered a lot of material

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course to another student if they have an interest in the topic, as well as if they're willing to put in the effort regarding the readings every week.
I would, the professor and TA's taught the material well and the course was laid out well.
Yes I would! I loved lectures and section discussions were fascinating.
It is one of the only options for South America so I would recommend it because it provided an overview but prepare for a much higher workload than other history classes.
Yes if you are interested in colonial Latin American history
